title: How to Make Dandelion Wine

steps.headline: Wash and clean the blossoms well.
steps.description: Think of it as a fruit or vegetable; you don't want bugs or dirt in your food. Remove all green material.

steps.headline: Place the blossoms in the four quarts of water, along with the lime, orange, and lemon juices.
Stir in the ginger, cloves, orange peels, lemon peels, and sugar.
steps.description: Bring the mix to a boil for an hour. This creates the 'infusion' that will later become wine after fermentation.

steps.headline: Strain through filter papers (coffee filters are recommended).
steps.description: Let the infusion cool down for a while.

steps.headline: Stir the yeast in while the infusion is still warm, but below 100 degrees F.
Cover it and leave it alone, let it stand overnight.

Pour it into bottles, poke a few holes in a balloon and place over the tops of the bottles to create an airlock, to keep out unwanted wild yeasts, and store them in a dark place for at least three weeks so that it can ferment.
steps.description: At this point you now have wine!

steps.headline: Rack the wine several times, optionally.
steps.description: Racking means waiting until the wine clears, then siphoning or pouring the liquid into another container, leaving the lees (sediment) at the bottom of the first container.

steps.headline: Cork and store the bottles in a cool place.
steps.description: Allow the wine some time to age. Most recipes recommend waiting at least six months, preferably a year.

tyn: 2 pots that hold at least 5 US quarts (4.7 L)
A thin plastic tube for siphoning
text: Wash and clean the blossoms well. Think of it as a fruit or vegetable; you don't want bugs or dirt in your food. Remove all green material. Soak flowers for two days.  Place the blossoms in the four quarts of water, along with the lime, orange, and lemon juices.  Stir in the ginger, cloves, orange peels, lemon peels, and sugar. Bring the mix to a boil for an hour. This creates the 'infusion' that will later become wine after fermentation. Strain through filter papers (coffee filters are recommended). Let the infusion cool down for a while. Stir the yeast in while the infusion is still warm, but below 100 degrees F.  Cover it and leave it alone, let it stand overnight.  Pour it into bottles, poke a few holes in a balloon and place over the tops of the bottles to create an airlock, to keep out unwanted wild yeasts, and store them in a dark place for at least three weeks so that it can ferment. At this point you now have wine! Rack the wine several times, optionally. Racking means waiting until the wine clears, then siphoning or pouring the liquid into another container, leaving the lees (sediment) at the bottom of the first container. Cork and store the bottles in a cool place. Allow the wine some time to age. Most recipes recommend waiting at least six months, preferably a year.
